b'I'm not OP but I would like to share my thoughts with you.

When the stomach is full, we can say it's a 100%, right?

When I binge, I feel like my stomach is on its 200%

Overeating for me feels like 120%, 150%, that's how I see it.

Overeating is "I'm having a second piece of cake because it tastes so good". But once you eat, you are done with it. You don't feel this compulsion of "KEEP EATING KEEP EATING DON'T STOP"'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'So clean and beautiful. Pure poetry.'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT:
b'Yes, I have the same issue.

My mom raised me under the "Clean your plate" method. I had to finish ALL. Otherwise she would get mad at me. "Look all the food you made me cook and you dont finish it". "We can't waste food, finish it all". "You can't go out to play unless you finish your food". When my binges occur, I have this voice in my head that says "FINISH IT FINISH IT FINISH IT". I could not keep a peanut butter jar in my house for months.

​

One time, a glass jar fell on the floor. I ate everything. Even pieces of glass. Yes, I know, this is madness. I hit rock bottom here.

​

I have been working a lot on this lately. I'm sharing what works for me: 

​

* I read Intuitive Eating and the "Clean Plate" issue is discussed in the book. You might give this book a try. Another book that helped me a lot: Eating Mindfully
* I eat at the table. No longer eating in the kitchen, standing, no longer eating in front of the tv. 
* You are not a trash can my friend. You are not the place where the leftovers end. It's okay to throw food away or save it for tomorrow. I always had this panic of "Mom will get mad if I don't finish my plate". Mom doesn't live with me anymore, I'm an adult, I can do whatever I want. I paid the food with my own money, I don't owe her anything.
* You need to learn to identify your hunger cues. STOP and think: Am I full? Does my stomach hurt? Can I stand up and walk without feeling like I have a bag of rocks in my stomach?
* If you want to eat something, prepare it at the kitchen, save jars, bags, everything in their place, go to the table, sit there, put the phone away, turn off the TV, eat slowly. Chew carefully. Ask yourself: Am I full? Do I feel satiated? Focus on the food and your feelings. Do you want Peanut butter? Ok, have some of it, put it on a cookie or something, put that in a plate, close the jar, wash the spoon, go and sit in the table. Eat. 
* Use your watch/clock. Try to spend AT LEAST 20 minutes eating. Fast eating and swallowing won't do you any good. If you spend more time with the food, you will feel satiated and you'll be able to stop before being too full.

​

​

I apologize for my english, it's not my first language.

​'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT:
b'I feel like we think about food because is the only thing that makes us feel good. At least for a couple of seconds. 
It\xe2\x80\x99s a mechanism from our brain to find the comfort we can\xe2\x80\x99t find somewhere else. Also, to numb yourself from dealing with other deeper and unknown issues. 

Just want to let you know that you are not alone here. I understand your feelings, your frustration, the sadness and the anger, the guilt that remains after everything is gone. The constant guilt. The feeling of being out of control.  The feeling of not being able to eat like a \xe2\x80\x9cnormal\xe2\x80\x9d person. 

I\xe2\x80\x99m very sorry that we all have to go through this and I hope that each of us can find some peace and something to soothe us that is not food. 
'

WRITING.TEXT: b">It's the thing that keeps us searching, the idea that somewhere, somebody has just the right words that spark a kernel of understanding in us\n\nOH MY GOD  THISSSSSSSSSSSSSSS!!!!!!!!!!!!"

WRITING.TITLE: b'Binge eating in front of others'
WRITING.TEXT:
b"I have been able to manage binges when I'm on my own with a lot of success.

However, being in front of others is a whole different story.

On saturday I attended a party and binged a lot. I don't drink alcohol so I was the only sober and was able to take over the food while the drunk people dance and laughed.

Yesterday I visited my boyfriend's parents and couldn't stop eating.

​

​

How do you guys manage eating in public?

I feel like for my it's a matter of social anxiety. I feel safer when I'm alone but I get so nervous in front of people, I don't pay attention to what they are speaking, I just think about the food and a voice tells me to EAT EAT EAT. I can't control it."

WRITING.TITLE: b'Mindful Eating'
WRITING.TEXT:
b'When it comes to binging, I also binge on information. I guess that if I continue researching and reading and learning I will finally have the skills to deal with this disorder.

​

Well, last week, first time of my life I had to deal with something I had never dealt before: Gastritis. Oh my God, it was awful. Food made me sick. I didn't want to eat. Eating was a living hell.. from binging like crazy to feeling nauseous and disgusted.

With some medication I finally started feeling better but something has changed. Before, everyone would be amazed of the amount of food I could eat, I could eat two pizzas in one sitting if I wanted. Now, after the gastritis, my stomach seems to have shrinked or something like that.

​

Anyway, as I couldn't go out during the weekend, I came across a book that has been mind blowing to me: Mindful Eating by Jan Chozen Bays.

​

I have read Brain over Binge and it didn't help a lot... but this one has make some kind of click in my heard. Basically, I've been eating in the wrong way all of my life. This book has taught me to actually focus on the food, tasting it, chewing it, paying attention to it and I'm feeling so different. I actually started to feel full, I never felt "full" before when eating, I could binge for hours and still feel unsatisfied. During the last couple of days, every meal takes me about 30 minutes and I actually feel satiated.

​

​

Anyway, just wanted to share something that has been working for me lately. Thank you for this space guys.

​

TL; DR: Try reading Mindful Eating by Jan Chozen Bays to improve your relationship with food and actually feel full after a meal and avoid binging.

​'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT:
b"Road Cycling!

​

I discovered cycling a year ago, I own 3 bikes now, 1 mountain bike and 2 road bicycles. I have changed my body, my mind, my sould, I have met new people. I have discovered thousand of places around my city that didn't know they even existed. I have found myself riding all alone between the mountains. I am faster than I was a year ago, however, I still find very very fast people and it's such a challenge to keep up with them. It's like there's always something to improve. I hate to wake up early to go to the office but I don't mind waking up at 4am on Saturdays and Sundays to go cycling. I love the process of getting ready to go out, I love the suffering and pain you go through when climbing up a moutain, the sensation of not having enough air inside your lungs. I don't know. It just makes me happy. It makes you feel ALIVE."

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT:
b"Sorry, but a lot of memories have come into my mind right now. It's funny how your brain makes you forget situations that were painful.

My mom would make me use the old pads from her store and cotton and this was not enough for my heavy periods. So a lot of my underwear had blood stains on it and she would get so mad at me, so I hid the dirty underwear in a box and would wash it at night in the bathroom when no one would see me. I couldnt hang those because she would see them so I hid them in a box while they were wet. Jesus. How can you get mad at a girl for having blood in her underwear?

​

She also got mad at me because she found blood on the car seat, my pants also had blood stains but you couldn't see them as they were dark pants. I also remember to stand up in highschool and when I looked at the white chair it was full of blood. My friends started lauhing at me. 

​

My teenage years were a living hell. God, I hated so much to be a woman. I started having peace of mind when my birth control pills ended with my periods."

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT:
b"Cotton.

​

My mother used to own a stored and she sold pads among other things. This was like 10 years before I got my period. She closed her store and kept all the products she couldn't sell. So I started using very old pads, the leftovers of the store. They were huge but they were not enough for my period so I had to add layers of cotton on top of them and on the sides to avoid leaks.

​

I recall that when the blood got dried on the cotton, it would hurt my skin so much. Every single period from 12 years to 18 (When my grandma could finally afford buying me tampons) was pure hell. I felt like I was using diapers. I'm pretty much a lot of people could tell I was on my period by the way I looked on pants. "
